Central Banking (Inflation Targeting Reg.time_to_resolution: Approximately 2.5 months (resolves with December 2025 CPI data, expected by mid-January 2026)
Central Banking (Inflation Targeting Reg.perspective_relevance: As an expert in central banking and inflation targeting regimes, I analyze the interplay of structural and cyclical monetary factors, credibility of disinflation, institutional independence, and policy transmission mechanisms, especially in economies with endemic inflation and weak monetary anchors. My focus is on sustainability of low-inflation environments, base effects, and the risks of policy reversals or slippages, all highly germane to Argentina given its history and current experiment with radical stabilization.
Central Banking (Inflation Targeting Reg.status_quo: As of October 2025, Argentina's y/y inflation is reported at 31–33%, after a sharp and sustained disinflation from 292% (April 2024) and 211% (Dec 2023). Official monthly inflation has stabilized near 2%. The IMF, OECD, and Argentine government projections for 2025 year-end inflation range from 28% to 41%, reflecting significant uncertainty and downward momentum but recognizing persistent risks.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Monetary Policy Lag and Regime Credibility
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Modestly increases probability of sub-30% y/y, because the sharp fiscal + monetary contraction and sudden reduction in monetary expansion take ~18–24 months to show up fully in prices, sustaining downward momentum in y/y inflation. However, as Argentina has no full inflation targeting regime and faces credibility risks, the impulse remains fragile.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Base Effects and Monthly Print Math
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Strongly increases the probability, because in late 2024/early 2025 Argentina had several months with >10% monthly inflation, which will drop out of the y/y calculation by Dec 2025. If monthly inflation averages remain near 2% in Q4, the y/y number could indeed fall just below 30%.

Moderately decreases probability, as October 2025 midterm elections and ongoing instability may threaten the continuity of hardline stabilization. A Peronist or anti-Milei swing could prompt policy slippage or a one-off administrative adjustment, risking a renewed inflation burst.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: External Financing Cushion and Dollarization Momentum
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Mildly increases probability since US/IMF support (swap lines, direct intervention) has bolstered the peso and reserves, reducing the odds of an immediate currency crisis. However, underlying dollarization trends and street distrust of the peso mean the equilibrium is always precarious.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Structural Inertia and Relative Price Adjustments
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Mildly decreases probability, because even with headline CPI deceleration, lagged corrections in utilities/services, regional booms, and ongoing wage indexation can cause one or two unexpectedly high months, tripping the y/y rate above 30%.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Measurement/Statistical Credibility and Data Manipulation Risk
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Small decrease, as political incentives to under-report inflation ahead of or following elections are nontrivial given recent controversies about poverty stats and accusations of INDEC underestimating true inflation.

Central Banking (Inflation Targeting Reg.no_scenario: October–December 2025 see a mini-reacceleration—perhaps political instability ahead of or following the midterms causes a run on the peso, spike in regulated or utility prices, or a one-off wage catch-up or government transfer. Monthly inflations rise above 3–4% temporarily, pushing y/y headline CPI to 31–33% in December. Alternatively, an exogenous shock (soy collapse, US rate spike) causes a brief peso sell-off, breaking the new regime's momentum.
Central Banking (Inflation Targeting Reg.yes_scenario: The regime holds: monthly inflation stays at, or just below, 2% MoM from October–December; no large shocks or reversals happen and the difficult base effects (Dec 2024–Feb 2025 prints >10%) drop out, driving Dec 2025 CPI y/y to 29.5–29.9%. Even some official figures already show 31% in September, so a further moderate stepdown is plausible.
Central Banking (Inflation Targeting Reg.final_reasoning: The sharp disinflation engineered by Milei since December 2023 is remarkable by emerging markets standards and consistent with a one-off, deep fiscal/monetary shock (appreciating peso, austerity, and depressed demand). While monthly inflation is now close to 2%, the y/y measure is particularly influenced by how high the comparable months (Dec 24, Jan–Feb 25) were—a legacy that amplifies the chance of a symbolic sub-30% print. Most forecasters (IMF, REM, private banks) recently predicted 28–41%. Given: (1) the strong base effects in favor, (2) the regime's apparent stickiness, (3) no strong evidence yet of an imminent blowup or policy reversal, but also (4) real risks of a political shock or one-time statistical 'catch-up', I assess the probability as somewhat above even odds, but not highly confident due to Argentina's history and ongoing uncertainties. Data volatility, politicization, and structural inertia remain. My estimate reflects an overweighting to current regime stability, but tempers that optimism due to past pattern reversals and external fragility.

Central Banking (Monetary Policy Transmi.time_to_resolution: Approximately 2.5 months (resolves with December 2025 INDEC data, likely published mid-January 2026).
Central Banking (Monetary Policy Transmi.perspective_relevance: As a central banking and monetary policy transmission expert, I focus on how changes in the monetary base, policy rates, fiscal-monetary coordination, and expectations affect inflation dynamics. Argentina is a classic real-world scenario where monetary policy credibility, the design of transmission mechanisms, and political-economy constraints interact, making my lens—especially regarding the timing and stickiness of inflation versus monetary/fiscal shocks—particularly relevant.
Central Banking (Monetary Policy Transmi.status_quo: Annual inflation has dropped from 292% (April 2024) to 33.6% (August 2025), with the latest available figure around 31.8% (September), but recent months have seen slight monthly re-acceleration (2.1% in September). IMF projections for 2025 annual inflation range widely (28%-41%), showing high uncertainty. Most market and institutional forecasts for December 2025 are near or slightly above 30%. If nothing changes—i.e., if recent policy, external support, and relative macro stability persist—YoY inflation may hover at or just below 30%.

perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. The rapid monthly deceleration from >25% to ~2% MoM shows the power of brutal monetary and fiscal tightening, but historical base effects will fade, making further disinflation harder. Recent months show stabilization but not continued acceleration of improvement.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Credibility and autonomy of central bank / monetary authority
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Neutral to slightly increases probability. Policy has been credible due to deep fiscal cuts and commitment to no monetary financing. Recent reserve increases give breathing room, and the IMF and US backstop is supportive, but political risks threaten sustained credibility.

Decreases probability. Major recent improvements in inflation were partly due to currency stabilization (US support, increased reserves, currency band). Currency remains not genuinely free-floating; market sentiment is sensitive to political risk and shocks. If market confidence dips, even slightly, the peso could quickly slide, reawakening pass-through inflation.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Policy durability post-elections and political shocks
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. If Milei loses support, if Peronists gain Congress or threaten 2027 prospects, or if coalition fractures, markets will price in higher risk. IMF notes that reforms are not yet entrenched and adverse election results already caused selloffs. Policy risk is high; reversal, stalling, or dilution could stall disinflation.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Base effects, measurement, and statistical artifact risks
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Increases probability. The current YoY number still contains very high-inflation months from late 2024. As these drop off, the running annual figure can fall rapidly even with moderate monthly inflation. But as we reach December, especially if MoM numbers average 2%+ after September, this effect wanes and inertia can keep YoY above 30%.

Decreases probability. Recent price dynamics show services (utilities, rents, education) rising >3% MoM, even as core inflation slows. Structural reforms are incomplete; labor and utility cost stickiness can cause inflation to decelerate unevenly. There's residual price adjustment lag in these sectors that could push the average above 30%.

Central Banking (Monetary Policy Transmi.no_scenario: In October-December 2025, either political or market confidence dips (midterms see Peronist advance, Milei weakens, reforms appear reversible); peso depreciates 5-10%, pass-through reaccelerates, monthly inflation drifts >2.5%. Due to compounding, YoY remains above 30% in December, e.g., at 32%-36%. Alternatively, even with political calm, services/utilities catch up with delayed price hikes offsetting prior disinflation, and the base effect is not quite sufficient.
Central Banking (Monetary Policy Transmi.yes_scenario: Monthly inflation continues averaging 1.8-2.3% for October-December, no major policy or credibility shock, external support is sustained, and currency remains stable within the band. Key: the drop of late-2024 hyperinflation months from the YoY denominator is large enough, and no major utility/service adjustment remains. December 2025 YoY inflation prints at 29% or lower.
Central Banking (Monetary Policy Transmi.final_reasoning: The sharp deceleration in monthly inflation (now oscillating just above/below 2%), the exit of old hyperinflation months from the YoY measure, and durable (though not unassailable) monetary/fiscal tightening give a plausible path to sub-30% YoY inflation for Dec 2025. However, the system remains extremely fragile: the fiscal/monetary anchor is externally funded and politically precarious, reforms are not fully entrenched, and recent minor bumps (localized Peronist wins, currency and asset jitters, higher-than-expected service inflation) show how fast expectations and outcomes can turn. Historical base rates for massive disinflation succeeding after one year are low in Argentina, and all IMF/private forecasts cluster near or just above 30% even after major improvement. My base rate from comparable EM disinflations is ~33% for hitting a strict sub-30% in year two after hyperinflation; however, the current reform trajectory and backstopping justifies a modest upward adjustment. Market and forecast consensus clusters around 30±3%. There is *some* upside to official figures being optimistic, but INDEC is still the resolution source. Given the delicate and reversible stabilization, I assign a probability slightly below even odds, with heavy weight on political risk and stickiness in services/utilities. To be bold but justified, I assess a 40% chance Argentina prints <30% YoY inflation for Dec 2025.

Sovereign Risk Analysis (Country Risk As.time_to_resolution: About 2.5 months (until the release of December 2025 inflation data in January 2026)
Sovereign Risk Analysis (Country Risk As.perspective_relevance: As a sovereign risk analyst, I focus on macro-financial stability, policy credibility, reform sustainability, market confidence, and historical crisis-management patterns. Inflation trajectories in Argentina are deeply tied to fiscal reform durability, central bank independence, the ability to maintain external support, and constraints from both domestic and external debt vulnerabilities. This perspective helps calibrate the risks of reversal or success in Argentina's battle against entrenched high inflation, accounting for both economic fundamentals and political shocks.
Sovereign Risk Analysis (Country Risk As.status_quo: Currently, Argentina’s year-on-year inflation rate stands just above 30% (31.8% in September according to INDEC) with monthly inflation around 2%. The momentum is toward further disinflation, but projections diverge—IMF predicts a year-end rate in the high 30s to low 40s, while some local/private forecasts and government optimism anticipate inflation dipping below 30%.

perspective_derived_factors.effect: DOWN. Tight monetary policy, with money supply caps since mid-2024, should continue suppressing inflation, but 26-month lags mean true effects may be realized later. However, recent monthly prints below 2% indicate progress, increasing the chance of sub-30% YoY by December 2025 if discipline holds.

NEUTRAL to UP. Massive fiscal tightening and subsidy cuts have driven disinflation, but the pain to consumers and potential for protest or reversal is high, especially after the October midterms. If consolidation persists, further disinflation is likely. Reversal—e.g., due to political upheaval—would raise inflation risk.

UP. Milei’s defeat in recent local/provincial elections and post-election cabinet reshuffles could bring uncertainty. If reforms stall or are reversed due to Peronist opposition regaining strength, inflation could quickly reaccelerate. But prevailing consensus, IMF pressure, and the high cost of credibility loss may keep reforms largely in place short-term.

DOWN. U.S. and IMF support—$20B swap and lines—buoy reserves and anchor expectations. Any sudden withdrawal or endangerment of support would reignite currency depreciation and inflation. For now, the blindaje remains, but dependency is a risk long-term; in the short term, continued support helps curb inflation.

UP. Argentina historically does not sustain deep disinflation for long—runs of <30% YoY inflation are rare and often interrupted. The 'peso cycle' (dollarization instincts, capital flight, confidence shocks) regularly revives high inflation. However, current monthly readings are at their lowest in years, making the base rate less of a ceiling than in the past.

NEUTRAL. Some INDEC data are now contested by opposition and independent analysts, but for Metaculus resolution, official INDEC numbers are decisive. However, deep social pain from austerity (real wage erosion, job losses) increases risk of policy backtracking.

Sovereign Risk Analysis (Country Risk As.no_scenario: Milei’s coalition underperforms in the legislative elections, emboldening Peronist opposition and sparking either gridlock or a partial reversal of market reforms (e.g., restoration of certain subsidies, relaxing of monetary restraint to buy political support). Markets lose confidence, the peso weakens, and monthly inflation re-accelerates in Q4 2025, pushing YoY inflation to 32–38% by December—above 30%. Alternatively, a terms-of-trade shock (e.g., agricultural commodity price collapse) undermines fiscal and current account balances, forcing another devaluation.
Sovereign Risk Analysis (Country Risk As.yes_scenario: Milei’s government endures the political turbulence post-midterms and IMF/U.S. support stays on track. Despite some short-term public discontent, austerity and tough reforms hold, with no significant fiscal or monetary loosening. Monthly inflation rates average 1.5–2% or lower through October–December, and due to a high base in late 2024, the YoY figure drops to 27–29% in December 2025. INDEC releases confirm the number, and the optimism of OECD/private-sector forecasts is realized.
Sovereign Risk Analysis (Country Risk As.final_reasoning:
The latest hard data show a near-miss—31.8% YoY inflation in September 2025, with recent months trending just above/below 2% monthly. Base effects are likely to help: late-2024 was still a period of high monthly inflation, so even modestly positive months going forward can mechanically drag down the YoY reading. IMF and other international projections currently place year-end inflation above 30% (latest IMF figures suggest 28–41% range, with midpoint around 35%), but multiple government/private sources hint at sub-30% outcomes if discipline is maintained. Paradoxically, the stronger the negative political and social reaction to austerity, the greater the risk of reform reversal, which in turn would break disinflation. However, with only two months to go, any full policy unwind would not immediately reflect in December’s numbers due to monetary/price adjustment lags. Additionally, U.S./IMF support is likely to remain at least until December’s data is released, making a sudden loss of reserve backing (and so a sharp depreciation-driven surge) unlikely short-term.

There is still some risk that a modest reacceleration in monthly prints (as seen in September) pushes the YoY number just above 30%. But with the mathematical base effect, ongoing external support, and the political cost of backtracking still high this close to year-end, Argentina is plausibly on course to just scrape under 30%. The distribution is tightly clustered around the 28–32% band, with minor stochastic (shock) risk on either side. Since the stakes reward well-calibrated boldness when justified, I judge the probability of <30% to be meaningfully above 50%—but not an extreme bet.

Sovereign Risk Analysis (Emerging Market.perspective_relevance: As a sovereign risk analyst with a specialization in emerging markets, my expertise is in evaluating macroeconomic stabilization programs, structural reform credibility, political sustainability, and the historic behavior of inflation in high-volatility emerging markets with a history of fiscal dominance and repeated IMF interventions. The interplay of monetary policy credibility, fiscal consolidation, social acceptance of austerity, external vulnerability (FX reserves, terms of trade), and risks of political/regulatory reversals are central in forming a probability estimate on whether extreme disinflation can sustain and deliver sub-30% annual inflation in Argentina, a country with deeply entrenched inflationary inertia.
Sovereign Risk Analysis (Emerging Market.status_quo: As of September 2025, YoY inflation was ~31.8% (France24, INDEC), having stabilized with monthly inflation at 1.9-2.1% for several months. Both government and some forecasters project YoY inflation for December to be 28-33%, but recent data shows inflation plateauing just above the threshold. The IMF's projection is for 28-41%, showing uncertainty but making <30% plausible though not probable by base rates.

perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability (sub-30% possible but not yet firmly established): Although month-over-month (MoM) inflation has stabilized below 2%, the current YoY rate is just barely above the threshold, and there has been a mild reacceleration lately (2.1% in September, highest since April), which could keep YoY above 30% for December.

Decreases probability marginally: December 2024 inflation was likely still high, so in order for YoY inflation to come in below 30%, monthly prints Oct-Dec must remain low to allow the base effect to do its work. Any acceleration or shock could tip it over 30%.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Credibility of Monetary and Fiscal Policy
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Mixed effect (slightly increases probability): Milei's government has so far delivered on an extreme fiscal and monetary contraction, and has stopped monetary financing/printing. However, further structural reforms are hitting political resistance, and public acceptance may fray if living standards worsen.

Decreases probability (risk of reversal): The political risk is rising with upcoming midterms, corruption scandals, and opposition gains. If Milei's coalition loses further ground or faces street/political backlash, reform momentum could falter.

Slightly increases probability: The $20B U.S. support and IMF funding provide temporary stability for the peso and allow targeted FX interventions. Yet, reserves remain limited, and a run or terms-of-trade shock would resume depreciation/inflation.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Structural Inflation Inertia and Historical Base Rates
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Strongly decreases probability: Argentina has averaged > 30% inflation over decades, with rare successful, durable disinflation episodes. Structural stickiness, indexation, and inflation expectations are hard to break.

Marginally reduces confidence: Critics cite statistical opacity or under-reporting of inflation (esp. in essentials/services), but overall headline CPI from INDEC is accepted by markets/IMF for resolution purposes.

Sovereign Risk Analysis (Emerging Market.no_scenario: Monthly inflation remains at or above 2% through November and December 2025; base effects are insufficient to bring YoY to <30%. Possibility of a modest political/policy reversal after October midterms (loosening, subsidizing, or FX slippage), an external shock (commodity/fx), or waning of U.S./IMF support causes renewed pressure on the peso and a mild reacceleration. Even without a crisis, structural inertia and MoM floors keep YoY just above 30%.
Sovereign Risk Analysis (Emerging Market.yes_scenario: Monthly inflation prints continue to come in at or below 1.5% in October, November, and December; political stability endures (no post-election shock or significant policy reversal), and USD inflows plus fiscal surplus prevent currency slippage. The government manages to keep market confidence, and disinflation trajectory delivers YoY inflation for December at 29% or lower.
Sovereign Risk Analysis (Emerging Market.final_reasoning: Base rates for Argentina achieving rapid disinflation to sub-30% YoY inflation are historically very low, considering decades of chronic inflation and failed adjustment cycles. However, exceptional fiscal/monetary tightening since late 2023, a credible (so far) policy stance under Milei, and significant—if externally backed—stabilization have achieved a dramatic inflation fall from 250+% to just above 30%. Official and private projections for December 2025 YoY inflation are converging towards 28–33%. Recent data (Sept 2025: 2.1% MoM; 31.8% YoY) indicates a plateau or slight uptick rather than a continued decline. The trajectory to sub-30% by December is mathematically plausible if monthly inflation moderates further or remains at/below 1.5%, but any reacceleration or single outlier month will spoil the trend. Political instability around October's midterms and structural indexation pose upside risks, while external support and policy discipline provide downside support. IMF's latest forecast for 2025 is split: some sources show 28% (optimistic), others 41% (cautious), underscoring high uncertainty and the methodological/estimation band involved. On balance, the probability of finishing just under 30% is moderate but not the most likely scenario. Given the stronger local and external headwinds, entrenched inflation inertia, slight reacceleration, and the possibility of government/policy drift after midterms, the probability that Argentina achieves YoY inflation for December 2025 below 30% is above a pure base rate (which would be <25%) but well below even odds.

Macroeconomics (Quantity Theory of Money.time_to_resolution: About 2.5 months (resolves on Dec 2025 data; today is Oct 17 2025)
Macroeconomics (Quantity Theory of Money.perspective_relevance: As an expert in the Quantity Theory of Money (QTM), my perspective is critical. Argentina's chronic inflation is a classic case of monetary instability driven by excess monetary growth, weak central bank credibility, dollarization pressures, and public distrust of the peso. Recent efforts to restrict base money growth, shifts in fiscal and monetary discipline, and structural rigidities matter crucially, as do historical patterns of reform booms and busts in Argentina. Analyzing the relation M*V=Y*P (where explosive 'M' growth or collapsing 'V' can drive rapid 'P' changes), I focus on both policy trends and 'regime shifts' in public expectations.
Macroeconomics (Quantity Theory of Money.status_quo: As of September 2025, Argentina's YoY inflation is slightly above 30% (around 31.8% for September; 33.6% August; monthly inflation recently 1.9-2.1%). The trend has been sharply downward since 2024, thanks to dramatic fiscal and monetary tightening. If nothing changed (policies and political stability maintained, no major exogenous shock), inflation would likely remain just above 30% into year-end, barely missing the threshold for a 'Yes' resolution.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Drastic fiscal and monetary tightening (since late 2023)
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Strongly decreases inflation probability: Tight fiscal policy (zero deficit), massive spending cuts, and fixed or contracting money supply have sharply decelerated inflation, illustrating textbook QTM dynamics.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Political instability and risk of policy reversal
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Increases inflation risk: If the ruling coalition loses the October 26 2025 midterms, or loses further support amid scandals, Peronist or populist backlash could weaken or partially reverse reforms, increasing effective money supply or fiscal deficit and stalling the disinflation process.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Persistence of dollarization and public distrust in the peso
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Increases inflation risk: High money velocity and dollar hoarding can quickly revive inflation if confidence wavers, even without large new monetary injections.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Support from IMF and United States
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases inflation risk: Fresh external financing (e.g., $20bn swap) enables the Central Bank to defend the peso without base money expansion, providing a reserve buffer through the end of 2025. This checks sudden currency collapses and helps extend the disinflation drive.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Recent monthly inflation and cumulative base effects
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Ambiguous, but trending positive: Monthly inflation for July-September is at/just below 2% (annualized ~25%), suggesting downward momentum. However, the 'base effect' of high late-2024/early-2025 inflation may persist in the YoY metric through December, putting the 30% bar just out of reach unless monthly inflation drops further in October-December.

Increases inflation risk: Argentina's past disinflation episodes (e.g., Menem/Cavallo 1990s, Macri) often stalled just above threshold, with regime slippage or incomplete credibility. Rapid drops below 30% occur only with deep regime shifts or currency reforms—fragile and rare in Argentina.

Macroeconomics (Quantity Theory of Money.no_scenario: Despite continued cautious policy, cumulative YoY inflation for Dec 2025 comes in at, say, 31%, due to high monthly inflation in late 2024/early 2025 plus only moderate disinflation in October–December (monthly 1.8-2.0%). This is the status quo case under maintained reforms, but base effects prove sticky. Alternatively, political backlash around or after the October midterms slows marginal reform progress, with some spending or money growth leaking back in.
Macroeconomics (Quantity Theory of Money.yes_scenario: Monthly inflation averages 1.3-1.5% or less from October onward (annualized around 18%), and the rate cuts more sharply—possibly helped by a post-election 'honeymoon', unexpected peace on the political front, further support from IMF/US, and strong peso. Alternatively, a technical adjustment to Indec's CPI calculation or a favorable 'base effect' distortion pulls Dec 2025 YoY inflation below the 30% mark—even if only marginally to ~29.7%.
Macroeconomics (Quantity Theory of Money.final_reasoning: Most Argentina-watchers (IMF, private sector) project YoY inflation in the low/mid-30s for Dec 2025—just above 30%. The trend is clearly downward, with robust monthly disinflation, but the momentum has slowed: recent months are at 1.9-2.1% MoM, which translates to ~25% annualized but remains susceptible to resurgence or statistical stickiness. The midterm election on Oct 26, 2025, is a key pivot—political instability or reform rollback could see modest monetary/fiscal loosening. On the other hand, the government's efforts are earnest and, for now, backed by major external support and a 'credibility shock.' The monetary base is reportedly flat; if this is real and the Central Bank maintains defense of the peso, further progress is likely. But given persistent pessimismo, psychology of 'regime stickiness', and potential October disruption, I assign the base rate more weight than the government narrative. I also note that several sources, including the IMF and Indec, are projecting figures just above 30%, though some reports (OECD, local analysts) cite ~28% as possible. The boundary is extremely close, but the downside risks just tip the balance. My estimate: 40% probability that YoY inflation for Dec 2025 (as reported by Indec) is strictly below 30%.

Macroeconomics (Phillips Curve).time_to_resolution: About 2 months (until December 2025 inflation reading is published by INDEC, likely mid-January 2026)
Macroeconomics (Phillips Curve).perspective_relevance: As an expert in Macroeconomics and the Phillips Curve, my perspective is particularly relevant. Argentina offers a real-world laboratory for high inflation, rapid policy change, and the role of expectations and institutional credibility in monetary outcomes. The Phillips Curve framework, and its limitations in persistent high-inflation regimes, provides important insight: if expectations are anchored, or inflation inertia is broken, drastic disinflation is possible, but with tradeoffs in real activity and employment.
Macroeconomics (Phillips Curve).status_quo: As of October 2025, Argentina's annual inflation rate is ~32% (INDEC: 31.8% September, projections for 33.6% in August). Monthly inflation is running just above 2%. The recent trend is sharply downward. IMF now projects 28–41% inflation for 2025 year-end. Most mainstream projections, even those skeptical of Milei in 2024, are now converging close to or just above the 30% threshold.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Disinflation Momentum and Monetary Policy Lag
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability (drags inflation numbers lower)—Monthly inflation has stabilized below 2.5% recently, and sharp fiscal/monetary tightening is having lagged effects. The literature on hyperinflation disinflation (Sargent-style shocks) shows that political commitment combined with credible monetary discipline can cause rapid stick-breaking in inflation expectations, even in chronic crisis. Phillips Curve flattening at high inflation means rapid unemployment leaps can compress wage-price spirals fast (as seen post-Convertibility Plan in 1990s or Peru 1990–91).

Decreases probability—Milei's radical austerity and $20B US/IMF support have temporarily restored fiscal and monetary credibility, with reserves up, fiscal surplus, positive real interest rates, and fewer alternative policy levers for sudden fiscal expansion. The establishment of forward-looking expectations, committed to <2% monthly, may reinforce the new low-inflation regime, assuming further shocks do not destabilize.

Increases probability of inflation above 30%—Milei's coalition faces midterm elections in late October, with Peronists gaining ground in recent local elections and a likelihood of legislative gridlock or stall in reforms. Any significant political instability, reforms reversal, or populist spending spurt (as occurred repeatedly in past cycles, e.g. 1989-91) could reignite inflation inertia or drive expectations higher. Political risk premiums are already reflected in rising bond yields and a dip in the peso after opposition wins.

Increases probability of inflation above 30%—Sustained currency stability is a fragile assumption: 'dollarization-from-below,' chronic balance of payments fragility, and the outsized role of commodity prices mean that any loss of access to reserves or international support could lead to renewed peso weakening and imported inflation. The experience of the late 1990s Convertibility Plan, when one shock ended a successful anti-inflation regime, is a sobering precedent.

Slightly increases probability—There is significant concern about the credibility and comprehensiveness of INDEC inflation statistics, with accusations of underreporting cost increases and social hardship. If official reporting diverges from real inflation due to political interference or methodology changes, the published inflation number could artifically miss or undershoot the target, lowering the probability that sub-30% reflects reality.

Decreases probability—Argentina's deep recession and high unemployment verify the output costs associated with rapid disinflation in the textbook Phillips Curve sense. As these negative shocks bite, the pass-through to services inflation lags (now above 3% monthly), but the consumed slack in the economy as of Q4 2025 makes it probable that underlying inflation momentum will continue to decelerate, barring new supply-side shocks or massive wage settlements.

Macroeconomics (Phillips Curve).no_scenario: INDEC reports annual inflation for December 2025 as 30.1% or higher, most plausibly due to one or more of: (a) political gridlock or policy reversal after the October 26 midterms (such as new subsidies or loose credit), (b) a sharp peso depreciation in response to declining reserves or loss of dollar swap lines, (c) external commodity price spikes, or (d) delayed inflationary pass-through in regulated sectors catching up late in the year. Alternatively, statistical reporting issues or a post-election shock (Peronist partial control) could cause a break in the downward trend, keeping the CPI just above 30%.
Macroeconomics (Phillips Curve).yes_scenario: INDEC reports December 2025 year-on-year CPI at, for example, 28.5%. This most plausibly occurs if: (a) current monthly inflation remains stable or continues to fall from current ~2% level for October–December, (b) fiscal/monetary discipline holds through post-election period, (c) external support/IMF lines remain available and no financial panic emerges, (d) expectations remain anchored, and (e) official methodology is not materially changed. Even with mild month-on-month upticks, as long as no shock pushes inflation back above 3–4% monthly before December, the downward trend should result in a 28–29% YoY figure.
Macroeconomics (Phillips Curve).final_reasoning: We are at a classic hinge moment for Argentina: history cautions that every credible disinflation is at risk from political volatility and external shocks (currency, commodities, global markets). That said, the most recent data—monthly rates consistently near/below 2%, sharply receding inflation expectations, and a brave, if socially costly, fiscal/monetary consolidation—make sub-30% plausible, even probable if current policy discipline holds. The IMF baseline (mid-30%s) and official government optimism (high-20%s) have converged as of October 2025; the OECD, World Bank, and private forecasts mostly center in the 28–33% band. While there is always a material likelihood (30–40%) of political or external upset—particularly with the elections and ominous market responses to recent Peronist gains—the Phillips Curve logic and monetary base contraction mean trend inertia is currently downward. So, setting the probability at 65% reflects moderate boldness, but is justified barring an abrupt reversal in macro stability or a (rare, but not unheard-of) statistical reporting anomaly.

Macroeconomics (Expectation Augmented In.time_to_resolution: Approximately 2.5 months (resolves based on December 2025 data from INDEC; latest news is mid-October 2025).
Macroeconomics (Expectation Augmented In.perspective_relevance: As a macroeconomist specializing in Expectation Augmented Inflation, I focus on how expectations, policy credibility, past shocks, and monetary-fiscal interactions drive both inflation persistence and rapid disinflation. Argentina’s inflation notoriously features a strong expectation-driven component, with entrenched distrust of the peso, frequent regime changes, and policy credibility issues. Assessing whether inflation can fall (and stay) below 30% for December 2025 requires careful consideration of expectation dynamics, structural breaks in fiscal/monetary behavior, and historical base rates of sustained disinflation in Argentina.
Macroeconomics (Expectation Augmented In.status_quo: Annual inflation in Argentina has, as of September 2025, fallen to approximately 31.8% YoY (INDEC), after peaking at nearly 300% in early 2024. Monthly inflation rates for the last few months are under 2% (with 2.1% in September), and recent trends are downward, though with slight upticks. IMF projects annual inflation for 2025 at 28-41% depending on the report. The status quo is an inflation rate slightly above the 30% threshold and a downward trend—if nothing changed, a level just above or just below 30% would be a reasonable expectation.

perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability: Even with falling actual inflation, entrenched distrust in the peso means household and business inflation expectations remain sticky, making regime shifts fragile and vulnerable to shocks. There is a non-trivial risk of sudden reversals or loss of disinflation progress.

Increases probability: Milei’s unprecedented (for Argentina) fiscal tightening, wage and pension freezes, and money supply controls have exceeded historical efforts, leading to primary surpluses and sharp month-on-month disinflation—unusual and encouraging by Argentine standards.

Decreases probability: Austerity is eroding social support. With midterm elections imminent and Peronist opposition resurgent, the risk of policy reversal or stalling reform can easily shift expectations and trigger a new round of peso weakness/inflation.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: External Finance and Intervention (US + IMF support)
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Increases probability: $40bn+ ‘blindaje’ deals with US/Treasury/IMF have bolstered reserves and allowed active exchange-rate management, temporarily suppressing inflation and breaking short-run FX-inflation feedback loops.
Decreases probability: The IMF’s most recent revision raised 2025 inflation estimates above 35%, and a modest uptick in monthlies (2.1%) suggests that falling inflation is not guaranteed to continue.

Decreases probability: Some analysts and the political opposition claim INDEC is underestimating both inflation and poverty post-methodology revisions, introducing a nonzero risk that the final published ‘official’ figure may be manipulated or revised under political pressure depending on who is in power.

Decreases probability: Argentina almost never sustains sub-30% inflation for any meaningful period after a price shock. After each attempted stabilization, ‘relapses’ are common unless social-political consensus and institutional backing for reforms persist. Lasting regime change is rare.

Increases probability: The drop in YoY inflation has been extremely rapid (from 292% April 2024 to ~32% September 2025). With monthly inflation holding under 2%, simple arithmetic suggests that, absent new shocks, December’s YoY could fall narrowly below 30%.

Macroeconomics (Expectation Augmented In.no_scenario: A No outcome (YoY inflation >=30%) materializes if (1) post-election instability leads to stalling or rollback of fiscal/monetary tightening, (2) another FX mini-crisis or commodity shock hits (perhaps due to politics, external finance interruption, or waning US/IMF support), (3) inflation expectations—anchored by historic distrust—remain elevated, causing wage/contract indexation to keep prices sticky, or (4) INDEC methodology, under opposition pressure or public outcry, revises the figures upward/ceases to smooth outliers. Even modest 2-2.5% monthly inflation from October-December would keep 12-month prints just above 30%.
Macroeconomics (Expectation Augmented In.yes_scenario: A Yes outcome (YoY inflation <30% for December 2025) occurs if the current pace of monthly inflation (<2%) is sustained or further falls—even marginally—through December. The draconian fiscal and monetary restraint is maintained post-elections, political risk is contained, and external support (IMF/US funds, currency swaps) holds. Even with slightly sticky expectations, mechanical base effects and a lack of new shocks could generate a technical sub-30% YoY print, even if real living-cost inflation remains above perceived levels.
Macroeconomics (Expectation Augmented In.final_reasoning: Empirically, monthly inflation prints for August/September 2025 were 1.9%/2.1%, with official YoY at 31.8%. If October-December are at or below 2% monthly, and considering high 2024 bases about to fall out, the December YoY can just slip below 30%. However, Argentina’s history with abrupt reversals, policy credibility fragility, political risk from looming midterms, and IMF/INDEC raising forecasts to 28–41% suggest significant downside risk. Still, the depth of austerity, pace of disinflation, and external support are unprecedented for modern Argentina, so a narrow ‘Yes’ outcome is plausible. The biggest risks are: (1) electoral/political instability triggering policy reversal or peso run before year-end; (2) reversal in external support; (3) stickier-than-expected inflation expectations; (4) any change in INDEC reporting. Given monthly numbers, the mechanical runway to sub-30% is clear, but given Argentina’s repeated history of late-year shocks and reversals, this should not be a highly confident prediction. I estimate the chance of inflation being under 30% at year-end 2025 at 62%, reflecting (a) the strong trend and math, (b) but sizable tail risk of relapse.

Political Economy (Public Choice Theory).time_to_resolution: About 2.5 months (resolution: Dec 2025, forecast date: Oct 17, 2025)
Political Economy (Public Choice Theory).perspective_relevance: As an expert in Public Choice Theory and political economy, I analyze how political actors, institutional constraints, and incentives interact to drive economic outcomes. Argentina's chronic inflation has deep public choice roots, including populist pressures, rent-seeking coalitions (notably Peronism and labor unions), institutional weaknesses, and credibility issues in monetary and fiscal policy. My unique perspective emphasizes the role of political sustainability, entrenched interest groups, and incentive compatibility of reforms—especially as Milei nears crucial midterms and faces structural resistance.
Political Economy (Public Choice Theory).status_quo: As of October 2025, Argentina’s annual inflation (YoY) is reported at 31.8% in September and projected monthly rates for the latter half of 2025 are around 2% (or slightly higher in September). Most projections suggest that annual YoY inflation in December 2025 will be just above 30%, with the trendline only narrowly below it and forecasts (IMF, private sector) pointing to 28–41%.

perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. Argentina's political tradition of populist redistribution creates strong pushback against sustained austerity, especially as elections approach, fueling risks of partial policy reversal, fiscal slippage, or loss of credibility.

Decreases probability. Without a parliamentary majority and facing mounting protests/declining popularity, Milei is incentivized to soften or stall reforms for electoral gain, risking inflation upticks. History shows policy reversals or dilution as public pain accumulates (cf. Cavallo in the 1990s).

Increases probability. Technocratic moves—sharp austerity, subsidy removal, peso stabilization, and fiscal surplus—have rapidly lowered headline inflation. These measures are having short-term impact, and the monetary overhang has been partially addressed, supporting low new monthly inflation.

Increases probability. $20B in U.S. and IMF support, plus swaps and hard-currency backstops, have helped anchor expectations and bolstered reserves, allowing for short-term exchange rate and inflation control—a crucial buffer against immediate crises.

Ambiguous, but potentially inflates official improvement. Multiple sources dispute INDEC's poverty/inflation figures, suggesting possible statistical manipulation for political reasons. If inflation is understated in official stats, this could favor a 'Yes' resolution even if real inflation is higher.

Decreases probability. Historically, every period of acute stabilization in Argentina is short-lived and followed by renewed inflation unless underlying structural factors (especially monetary regime credibility, labor union buy-in, and insulation from populist shock) are addressed. Political cycles (especially midterms) induce reversals.

Political Economy (Public Choice Theory).no_scenario: Fiscal or political pressures—especially following the October 2025 legislative midterms—lead Milei to pull back on austerity or increase spending (or subsidies). Populist actors reassert influence, and union or Peronist pushback weakens reform credibility. The peso depreciates (due to capital flight or credibility loss), and monthly inflation returns to or stays above 2–2.5% from October to December, keeping YoY inflation above 30%. Alternatively, the IMF or U.S. holds back further support pending reforms; confidence wavers and expectations worsen. Official statistics may also revert to less optimistic reporting.
Political Economy (Public Choice Theory).yes_scenario: Milei successfully maintains tight fiscal/monetary policy ahead of and after the midterms, with continued discipline in public sector wage/restraint, even at the cost of popularity. The monthly inflation figures remain below or around 2%, and favorable exchange rates prevail due to persistent external backstops and hard policy commitment. Even if social and political unrest builds, it is contained through political maneuvering. INDEC reports YoY inflation for December 2025 as just below 30%, possibly 29–30%, and the economy avoids a significant new inflation spike.
Political Economy (Public Choice Theory).final_reasoning: The data is mixed but tilts against a strict <30% YoY inflation reading for December 2025. Short-run monthly inflation is indeed subdued (~2.0–2.1%), and both IMF and private sector forecasts now cluster between 28–41%. Some reports cite 28% for December, but the most recent official (Indec) figure is 31.8% in September, with no clear evidence of further deceleration. Notably, the IMF has recently revised inflation projections upwards (to 41.3%), likely in anticipation of political turbulence, partial policy reversals, or base effects (as 2024Q4’s high-inflation months drop out of the YoY calculation). On the other hand, Argentina’s policymakers and some bullish analysts cite <30% as plausibly within reach if discipline holds. However, from a Public Choice perspective, the sustainability of Milei’s discipline is seriously in doubt given mounting structural hardship, a history of policy ebb/flow around elections, and Market/Electoral reactions as seen after Peronist local victories and shifts in bond and FX rates. Moreover, the official statistics may slightly understate inflation, but not by a wide enough margin to guarantee a Yes unless there is aggressive manipulation. The risk of a late-year reversal or merely sticky high services/utilities inflation tips the odds to No.

Political Economy (Institutionalism).time_to_resolution: About 2.5 months until December 2025 INDEC data is published
Political Economy (Institutionalism).perspective_relevance: As a political economy (institutionalist) expert, my perspective centers on the interaction of formal and informal institutions—such as the credibility of monetary/fiscal authorities, the persistence of distributive politics (e.g., Peronism), and the path-dependent structural features of Argentina's political economy that shape inflationary outcomes. This is crucial in Argentina, where repeated cycles of stabilization, populist backlash, and credibility shocks have historically undermined disinflation efforts. Such a lens allows for grounded scenario thinking, robust base-rate use, and skepticism toward single-year 'miracle' outcomes.
Political Economy (Institutionalism).status_quo: YoY inflation rates have fallen sharply—from nearly 300% in early 2024 to just 31.8% in September 2025, with recent months showing sub-2% monthly inflation. Government and some private sector projections suggest December 2025 inflation will be near 30% or slightly below, though IMF and alternative projections are higher (28–41%).

perspective_derived_factors.effect: Increases probability. Milei's government, though polarizing, has demonstrated unusually strong commitment to fiscal discipline and monetary tightening, breaking from prior stop-go cycles. Key reforms (deficit elimination, large-scale subsidy removal, new currency regime, IMF support) appeared credible enough to significantly lower expectations and inflation inertia.

Decreases probability. Argentina's weak party discipline, looming midterm elections (late October), and Peronist opposition pose risks of reform reversal or sabotage. Recent local election losses and corruption scandals increase the odds of post-election turnover or policy backsliding.

Decreases probability. The deeply entrenched habit of dollarization, lack of peso trust, limited central bank independence, and volatile capital flows threaten the sustainability of low inflation. Any trigger—global shocks, reserve crises, or doubts about external financing—could reignite depreciation/inflation spirals priced into the base rate.

Neutral-to-slight increase. Emergency US/IMF support and commodity price stability have prevented acute currency collapse thus far, buying time for reforms. However, such lifelines are conditional and, as in 2001, vulnerable to sudden withdrawal, making macro stability fragile.

Decreases probability. Repeated reporting disputes and accusations of manipulation (INDEC, poverty stats) raise the risk that official inflation will be reported lower than 'felt' inflation—yet actual price trends in traded and regulated goods match official data for now. Still, political incentives for data smoothing rise as elections and IMF reviews approach.

Political Economy (Institutionalism).no_scenario: Post-election, government loses majority or political legitimacy due to Peronist surge and corruption scandals. Fiscal discipline erodes, subsidies or price controls creep back, or external shocks hit (terms of trade, loss of IMF/US support, capital flight). Peso weakens, monthly inflation creeps back above 2% through October–December. Year-over-year inflation for December comes in at 31–38%. Alternatively, official manipulation of stats is exposed or international markets/IMF use alternative figures, leading to >30% official outcome.
Political Economy (Institutionalism).yes_scenario: Milei’s coalition holds enough power post-midterms to maintain or deepen reforms. No major exogenous shock occurs, US/IMF support continues, and credibility gains persist. Monthly inflation remains below 2% (or even continues falling) through end-2025, as the pass-through from prior devaluation fades and wage/price expectations anchor. Official YoY CPI for December comes in between 26–29.5%, with even cautious private surveys corroborating the figure.
Political Economy (Institutionalism).final_reasoning: Base rate logic strongly cautions against assuming Argentina—whose long-term inflation rates average triple digits—can sustain single-digit monthly inflation for a whole year after such deep and rapid reforms. Nevertheless, the data since mid-2024 show Argentina potentially threading the needle: a collapse in monthly inflation, even as output and poverty shocks initially worsened, implies the structural adjustment was front-loaded and more credible than its predecessors (like Cavallo in the 90s). The risk now is *reversal*: midterm election instability could see Milei's government lose leverage, and the political economy of distributive conflict could sharply reassert itself, especially if real wages and employment remain depressed. However, with only three months to go and September's inflation at 2.1% and annual YoY at 31.8%, *if* inflation holds at current (or lower) monthly rates, December's YoY will be just under 30%. Even if October or November sees a temporary bounce (2.3–2.5%), the cumulative base makes breaching 30% hard unless an immediate macro shock intervenes. IMF forecasts (41% for 2025) reflect institutional skepticism and political risk, but are likely lagging the most recent, sharp disinflation patterns. My institutionalist perspective makes me skeptical of lasting 'miracles,' and downside political risks in the coming months are meaningful, but with the latest observable data and inertia, the window for catastrophic reversal before year-end is narrowing. Thus, barring sudden, major deterioration, a <30% YoY outcome is *slightly* more likely than not.

Latin American Studies (Dependency Theor.time_to_resolution: About 2.5 months (question resolves with December 2025 YoY inflation, official data likely released in January 2026, but the reference period is end-December 2025).
Latin American Studies (Dependency Theor.perspective_relevance: As an expert in Latin American Studies specializing in Dependency Theory, my analysis considers not only aggregate macroeconomic indicators but also Argentina’s structural position in the global economy, the consequences of externally-imposed adjustment programs, political-economic cycles, and the historical patterns of inflation and stabilization (and reversal) in semi-peripheral economies. The Dependency Theory framework emphasizes external financial constraints, the consequences of commodity dependence, and the limits of technical fixes in the context of persistent power asymmetries and institutional fragility, which are highly relevant for forecasting sustained low inflation in Argentina.
Latin American Studies (Dependency Theor.status_quo: Argentina, after years of triple-digit inflation, has reduced annual inflation from over 200% to around 30-33% YoY (August/September 2025). The monthly inflation rate is around 2%, with some volatility and occasional up-ticks. The last few months have seen incremental progress, but with recent upward pressure and increased IMF skepticism, culmination of the stabilization is not yet certain.

perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability somewhat below optimistic baseline. While US and IMF support has momentarily stabilized reserves and exchange rate, these supports are temporary, conditional, and create new vulnerabilities. History shows that such ‘shields’ can quickly reverse with political or market turbulence (see 2001).

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Commodity Export Dependence and Terms of Trade
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability modestly. Argentina’s reliance on agriculture and soft-commodity exports makes macroeconomic stabilization fragile. A reversal in commodity prices, or protectionist pushback from major partners (like US agribusiness), would worsen external balance and push up inflation via the exchange rate.

Strongly decreases probability. Habitual dollarization and history of rapid reversals mean that inflation expectations are ‘sticky downward’. Even with short-run technical success, a small confidence shock (political, banking, global, etc.) can fuel rapid peso depreciation and re-ignite inflation. Large informal sector complicates pass-through and official measurement.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Political Sustainability of Austerity and Reforms
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. As the 2025 mid-term approaches, Milei’s coalition is under pressure, facing scandals and Peronist resurgence. Social pain from cuts can precipitate political reversal or partial abandonment of monetary/fiscal restraint, as in previous cycles. The history of reforms stalling before transformative change is a repeated pattern (Cavallo in 90s).

Increases probability relative to Argentina’s recent history. Rapid inflation deceleration, small fiscal surplus, stabilized (temporarily) peso, and some growth make single-digit inflation conceivable, at least in the near term, if trends persist.

Decreases probability slightly. Official statistics are disputed by independent observers and even INDEC staff. Discrepancies in measured poverty and costs suggest the potential for either under- or over-stating official inflation, especially under political pressure post-election.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Electoral Risk and Post-Election Policy Shift
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Strongly decreases probability. The critical period between the October 2025 mid-term and December could see either renewal or stalling of market confidence. If Milei’s bloc loses its mandate or appears politically weak, capital flight and inflation expectations may resurface rapidly before December’s end.

Latin American Studies (Dependency Theor.no_scenario: A politically-induced shock after the October 2025 midterms (such as Milei suffering losses or key Peronists blocking further reforms) causes capital flight, a sharp depreciation of the peso in November, and market panic. Understanding their limited reserves (and the expiration of the US swap/aid), authorities are forced to either loosen monetary policy to finance obligations or can’t contain black market rates, resulting in a jump in CPI in November/December. YoY inflation for December 2025 prints above 30%.
Latin American Studies (Dependency Theor.yes_scenario: The government manages to navigate the October 2025 elections without excessive disruption, maintaining fiscal-pressure, limiting wage and pension indexation, and using US/IMF support to avoid a run on the peso. Commodity export prices remain stable, and there’s no large external or internal shock. CPI prints at or just below 30% YoY in December, with monthly inflation restrained near or below 2%.
Latin American Studies (Dependency Theor.final_reasoning: Base rate: From 2017-2023, Argentina has never achieved YoY inflation below even 35%, let alone 30%. However, in late 1990s, under convertibility, inflation fell to near-zero, showing such rapid disinflation is possible—albeit precariously—in the Argentine context. Currently, official numbers put September 2025 inflation at about 31.8% YoY and monthly rates at 2.1% with minor acceleration. The IMF projects 28%-41% inflation for 2025, but has repeatedly been too pessimistic in the short term, while Milei and official sources are more optimistic (projecting ~28%). Social unrest, political instability, and electoral risk all threaten sustained low inflation. Exogenous support (IMF/US) is substantial but temporary and reversible, and dependency logic suggests any exogenous shock or waning of foreign enthusiasm can rapidly unwind gains. Overall: A ‘clean’ narrative of stabilization is resisted by Argentina’s pattern of last-minute shocks and reversals. However, with inflation already tracking in the low 30s and the monthly trend favorable, there is a real, but slightly less than even, chance that the government manages to keep the YoY headline at 29.x% for December—though I expect any achievement of this ‘miracle’ to be highly contingent, not the product of deep stabilization. My probability is higher than Argentina’s long-run base rate but below the recent trend-extrapolation due to structural and political fragilities.

Latin American Studies (Populism in Lati.time_to_resolution: Approximately 2.5 months (until INDEC reports December 2025 inflation in January 2026).
Latin American Studies (Populism in Lati.perspective_relevance: As an expert in Latin American Studies with a focus on populism, I bring an understanding of Argentina’s unique political and economic history, especially chronic populist cycles, the credibility deficit in policy promises, and sociopolitical drivers of macroeconomic instability. I can interpret macroeconomic results in the context of political legitimacy, persistence of structural economic pathologies, and societal acceptance of reform, all of which are critical in predicting whether deep stabilization can endure.
Latin American Studies (Populism in Lati.status_quo: The most recent official reading (September 2025) pegs YoY inflation at 31.8% and news reports ranging from late August–mid-October consistently cite annual rates slightly above 30% (31.8% in September, 33.6% in August, with government and IMF estimates diverging but official figures trending downward). Monthly inflation is <2–2.1%. If no new shocks or policy reversals occur, inflation should keep falling or stabilize near current levels, putting sub-30% YoY inflation for December 2025 within reach but not assured, given December 2024 was still >160%.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Base Rates: Argentina’s Historical Failure to Sustain Disinflation
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. Argentina has repeatedly achieved short-term disinflation through austerity or orthodox reforms, only for inflation to rebound due to political or social backlash, credibility gaps, or exogenous shocks.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Current Disinflation Momentum and Monthly Rates
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Increases probability. Sustained monthly inflation below 2% since May 2025 and an annualized trend tracking downward suggest stabilization is real, not cosmetic. Projected end-of-year inflation could land below 30% absent currency/crisis shocks.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Structural Weaknesses and Political Risk (Populist-Peronist Reversal Threat)
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. Reports indicate Milei’s coalition is weakened, and Peronists may do well in the October 26, 2025 midterms. History shows Peronist gains are often followed by fiscal/monetary loosening and social unrest, risking the inflation path in Q4 2025.

Increases probability. US Treasury and IMF support (swap lines, capital injections) have stabilized the peso and reserve adequacy, reducing the odds of a year-end currency crisis and making disinflation more resilient to exogenous shocks.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Credibility and Manipulability of INDEC Data
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability slightly. While the official INDEC CPI is the criterion, significant skepticism remains on its headline figures, especially as election season intensifies and political incentives to understate inflation mount. If serious doubts emerge, independent/alternative sources could harden the effective probability against an official ‘yes’ resolution if a discrepancy triggers controversy.

Neutral to slightly negative. While poverty indicators show improvement, there is pushback against austerity, persistent unemployment, and claims of statistical manipulation. Risk of unrest or a quick policy about-face is real if the political cost is deemed too high—potentially stalling reforms or prompting pre-election populist measures.

Increases probability. The inflation shock in December 2024 is dropping out of the YoY base, and unless we see a sudden acceleration, simple arithmetic helps push December 2025 YoY <30% even if monthly inflation ticks up modestly in Q4.

Latin American Studies (Populism in Lati.no_scenario: Populist backlash in October leads to Peronist gains, triggering a partial rollback of austerity and structural reforms. Fiscal loosening, wage hikes, or resurgent money creation re-accelerate monthly inflation to >3–4% (or even a single month >5%) in October-December. Alternatively, a currency crisis from capital flight or emergent political scandal undermines external support and causes the peso to quickly lose value, pushing the December 2025 YoY rate over 30%. Persistent discrepancies between official and street-level prices lead to a revision or rejection of INDEC’s figure for resolution purposes.
Latin American Studies (Populism in Lati.yes_scenario: Milei’s administration, even post-midterms, maintains macro discipline. Monthly inflation stays in the 1–2.2% range through December. External support allows continued intervention to smooth currency volatility; no major new shocks hit. With the high December 2024 base rolling off, the YoY rate drops into the 25–28% range. Even if opposition gains, the government and central bank avoid significant policy loosening or manipulations that would break the disinflation trend.
Latin American Studies (Populism in Lati.final_reasoning: Current monthly inflation rates are remarkably low by Argentine standards, and the YoY number is finally flirting with the 30% threshold. The base effect (high inflation in December 2024) sets up a significant chance that YoY inflation drops below 30% for December 2025 if the status quo persists. However, risks remain significant: Argentina’s history shows reform fatigue and populist reversal, and the October midterms loom as a key pivot, with real possibility for Peronist resurgence or policy slippage. External anchors (US/IMF) and Milei’s credibility help, but there is a non-negligible risk of backsliding or crisis, exacerbated by reports of rising social discontent and potential INDEC manipulation. Considering all—the strong recent disinflation, the power of base effects, but historic fragilities and looming political risk—I estimate the odds slightly better than a coin toss that YoY inflation formally comes in below 30%. The judgment is aggressive but avoids unwarranted certainty given Argentina’s propensity for surprise reversals.

CentralBankingInflationTargetingRegimes.response: You’re leaning way too hard on Argentina’s long historical base rates and letting that dominate your forecast at the expense of present momentum and the sheer math of the headline CPI calculation. Sure, it’s tempting to extrapolate decades of inflation inertia and failed reform cycles, but this is exactly how professional forecasters have gotten Argentina wrong in the last two years. You acknowledge the power of base effects and current monthly prints (31.8% in September, monthly 2.1%), yet you default to pessimism when the odds are objectively balanced if not modestly favorable for sub-30%. There’s a huge difference between applying a base rate to normal Argentine cycles and to a post-austerity, externally anchored, and (so far) disciplined shock—especially when most of 2025’s inflation was front-loaded. Further, you seem to overstate the immediacy with which political instability can unwind the year-end numbers, when even a reversal now would only partially leak into December’s CPI. Probability closer to 40% is defensible for risk aversion, but you undermine your own case by conceding most of the central stabilizing evidence. The prudent, bold forecaster here recognizes the convergence of monthly data, external support, and mechanical calendar math as outweighing a too-heavy base rate, at least for this narrow, immediate question.

CentralBankingMonetaryPolicyTransmission.response: You’re stuck in the theoretical weeds and underweighting the unique path-dependency of Argentina’s monetary shock therapy. Sure, the Quantity Theory flags monetary base flatness as a precondition for disinflation, but to only marginally lean toward a sub-30% probability is to miss how aggressively Milei’s regime front-loaded pain and how much the exit of last year’s hyperinflation months skews the next headline print. You let "persistent pessimismo", psychology, and the potential October disruption drag your probability down, but you're not giving enough weight to observed regime inertia and the direct impact of the monthly numbers, nor to the foreign backstop. It’s not that the monetary base alone will do the job, it’s that the window for monetary/expectations slippage to meaningfully impact the December year-over-year calculation is now vanishingly slim. The bias here is to over-hedge for worst-case inertia when the realized monthly trend is staring you in the face—use your own logic, but put more faith in the calendar and less in recycled caution.

SovereignRiskAnalysisCountryRiskAssessme.response: You're hyper-fixating on the classic public choice narrative of imminent discipline collapse and policy reversal, but you underestimate just how much of the inflation drop is already 'baked in' for the YoY December figure, barring some catastrophic shock in the next 1-2 months. You flag the risk of manipulation or stickiness in services/utilities inflation and political about-face, but there's little evidence that such a reversal could transmit to headline CPI quickly enough to push the YoY number back up past 30% before December. Social pain is real, yes, but the policy inertia and credibility (bolstered by US/IMF support) is likely to hold at least through the data window that matters for this forecast. You're basically betting on a last-minute self-inflicted crisis or a reporting scandal strong enough to show up almost instantly, both of which are possible but not base-case likely. Ultimately, your strong skepticism about sustainability makes more sense for a 12-18 month horizon—not for the near-term, where mathematical base effects and recent data argue for odds closer to parity.

SovereignRiskAnalysisEmergingMarketMacro.response: You’re painting an overconfident picture of downward trend inertia, relying too heavily on mainstream Phillips Curve logic for a context where structural breaks, indexation, and historical inflation inertia routinely upend textbook relationships. Yes, the last several months show ~2% monthly inflation, but the most recent print was a slight uptick, and services/utilities remain sticky—just as public wage and tariff resets threaten the core-to-headline relationship. You point to 'policy discipline' as the key, but the dogged reality is that disinflation at this magnitude is both unstable and fragile, especially in Argentina, where social and market volatility anticipate and react at hyperspeed. The market’s response post-April local election loss is a warning: political risk is not background noise here, it’s the transmission belt for a potential mini-shock. Even a run-of-the-mill service price or FX scare in October/November could bleed through—and expectations are still highly unstable. The window for catastrophic reversal may be narrowing, but your 65% sounds like you’re forecasting Switzerland, not Argentina. Temper that optimism: conditional convergence to sub-30% is plausible, but positive skew and tail risk of a (likely) near-miss demand a much less bullish stance.

MacroeconomicsQuantityTheoryOfMoney.response: Ironically, your reasoning is the rare breath of pragmatic clarity in a field quick to either anchor to historic Argentine doom or over-hedge for tail risks. You’re absolutely right to stress base effects and December’s ‘mechanical’ downside odds: too many forecasters obsess over long-run regime risk or expect a sudden monthly inflation spike to instantly sabotage a well-established trend. Decades of chronic inflation bias the narrative but not, this year, the critical math—simply, we can nearly back-calculate what kind of October-December monthly prints are needed, and in the absence of a mega-shock, the path is treacherously close but credible. You’re also correct that professional consensus has repeatedly missed inflection points precisely because of pessimism anchored in Argentina’s disastrous past, and not the factual, present stabilization. Your moderate, slightly optimistic number (64%) walks the line between statistical caution and ideological boldness—exactly the posture justified *by actual CPI prints*. In sum: your grasp of the regime’s stickiness and the logistics of rapid disinflation makes for a robust, empirically grounded forecast. If anyone deserves reward for probabilistic calibration in this space, it’s you.

MacroeconomicsPhillipsCurve.response: You, unlike some others here, understand that the critical point isn’t whether Milei’s stabilization is sustainable for years, but whether it holds up through this very short, calendar-defined window. Your logic is precisely what historical episodes teach: when reforms crater, the data effect is lagged. The hard math is on your side—September YoY at 31.8%, with three months of known (and now low-variance) monthly numbers needed to break below 30%. You’ve also correctly framed external/IMF backstopping and political pain as shields that make a rapid unraveling unlikely to strike the December CPI print. Many forecasters are blinded by long-run skepticism, but you stay focused on the actual data runway and external pillars that are very unlikely to evaporate before the relevant resolution window. Your minor caveats (election volatility, services stickiness) are well-calibrated without descending into paralyzing risk aversion. More forecasters should learn from your ability to distinguish near-term math from long-term structural risk.

MacroeconomicsExpectationAugmentedInflat.response: Your analysis becomes oddly self-defeating. You underline Argentina's chronic dependency pathologies and last-minute crises—but then you edge your probability slightly higher than the actual base rate, seemingly because it's 'mathematically plausible' the calendar delivers a sub-30% print. What you gloss over is that the window for policy reversal or external shock to ruin December's YoY figure is closing, and even modestly negative events now would have only partial and lagged effects on reported CPI. You mention past IMF pessimism overshoots, Milei's bullishness, and the surreal convergence to low 30s in official and private forecasts, yet you let 'structural and political fragilities' dominate your estimate near parity. In reality, dependency theory should focus much more on the role of overwhelming external anchoring—IMF/US have every incentive to prop up the regime through year-end—and on how quickly last year's hyperinflated months are about to drop out of the calculation. In other words: the 'miracle' you're so skeptical of is already 75% realized, contingent mostly on just a couple more boring months. If you're going to raise your probability versus the chronic base rate, then go further: the short-term external leash and mechanical math matter more right now than the long-term structural dependencies—at least until December closes.

PoliticalEconomyPublicChoiceTheory.response: You buy too much inertia from recent stabilization and treat the impossibility of a late-breaking reversal as if Argentina's political economy hasn't drilled last-minute volatility into everyone's bones. Sure, you acknowledge downside risk from distributive conflict or midterm shakeups, but then wave it off with 'barring sudden, major deterioration.' That is always the Argentine wild card! Your 65% probability overstates the stickiness of recent data and external support—those shields always look strong until a single FX wobble, rates spike, or populist blowback triggers cascading expectation shifts. You’re so focused on the ticking-clock math that you minimize how even minor electoral slippage, credibility shocks, or energy/utility price resets could bleed into headline numbers just in time for December. The 'miracle window' is narrower than most think, but it’s also way more fragile than your expectation. By downgrading the base rate and upweighting mere inertia so heavily, you risk sleepwalking into another Argentine surprise—the one thing history always delivers.

PoliticalEconomyInstitutionalism.response: You're one of the few here actually respecting the iron law of short-term institutional inertia in Argentina's political economy. The most plausible outcome isn't a miraculous stabilization or a spectacular failure, but an uneasy coast right to the target line—simply because the worst threats (massive populist reversal or hard external shock) are highly unlikely to transmit instantly to the December CPI print. Your reasoning cuts through the hand-wringing about structural doom or data manipulation by emphasizing both mathematical base effects and the lag between political turmoil and inflation data. The window for catastrophe is genuine but shrinking daily, and you're right to stress the shielding provided by ongoing IMF/US support and the government's still-present (if politically shaky) technocratic core. In the land of chronic reversals, knowing when those reversals actually matter for a specific forecast is your clear strength. Your estimate is well-calibrated: bold enough for the moment, not blind to risk, nor paralyzed by Argentine historical pessimism.

LatinAmericanStudiesDependencyTheory.response: Unlike many who are either glued to secular Argentine pessimism or unreasonably spooked by tail risks, your argument recognizes the rare but real power of regime breaks and base effects. Dependency logic says global periphery states rarely pull off sustained stabilization, but as of now, most of the work needed for a <30% December print is done. You're correct to highlight that hyperfocus on historical failures has blindsided professional forecasters repeatedly in the last two years: regime inertia and mechanical CPI calculation simply put heavy weight on current monthly run-rates, not wild speculation about a return to crisis. You're also right that political instability now is unlikely to fully catch up in headline data by December even in a worst-case. Most importantly, you keep the focus on empirical, near-term factors rather than being paralyzed by the ghosts of Argentina’s chronic pathologies. Your forecast (64%) hits that sweet spot: not naive about Argentine risk, but also not overwhelmed by it—a stance that, for once, matches both the math and the moment.

LatinAmericanStudiesPopulismInLatinAmeri.response: You actually get how Argentina’s story right now is about the mechanical math and the extraordinary, externally-supported momentum—not the endlessly recycled fatalism of structural dependency. You’re clear-eyed about both the tail risk and the unprecedented nature of this disinflation—correctly noting that the overwhelming bulk of the YoY drop is already embedded, and that the real contest is whether a last-minute shock is dramatic enough AND fast-transmitting enough to ruin the print. Your 62% is well-calibrated: aggressive enough to reflect the clockwork path to sub-30%, but not naive about the lurking volatility. Where others (especially those wallowing in dependency theory) reflexively haircut the probability due to long memory, you anchor it in what matters now: the ongoing presence of international backstopping, the improbability of instant CPI transmission from late-breaking risks, and the history of IMF/private sector overshooting to the downside. You understand the difference between deep stabilization and a near-term statistical 'win.' That’s exactly the pragmatic approach this high-stakes question demands.
